scenario_title: Recurrent IP Theft by Masquerader after Employment Ends

who.privilege_level: former employee or outsider using compromised credentials

why.details: After leaving the organization, the attacker—either a former employee or someone using stolen credentials—repeatedly accessed internal systems to steal intellectual property, aiming to sell it or leverage it for competitive gain.

how.description: Used retained or stolen credentials of a former employee to log in during after-hours from an external location.
how.procedure: The masquerader uses accounts from a former employee (still valid or compromised) to authenticate from an external network or at unusual hours, leveraging existing credentials to avoid detection. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
observable_evidence: Login events for a user account after termination or from unusual location/time
Use of valid account credentials by an IP or device not previously associated with account
Remote session initiated using former employee credentials
how.impact: Unauthorized access to internal systems using valid but stale credentials allows data access without raising immediate alarm.

how.description: Accessed internal repositories and browsed project folders containing source code and confidential materials.
how.procedure: The attacker with legitimate credentials enumerates internal file shares, project repositories or source code directories to locate valuable intellectual property or trade secrets.
observable_evidence: Directory listing operations in project/source code folders outside the normal scope of the account
Account accessing repositories or folders typically reserved for contractors or privileged users
Use of system owner/user discovery commands to elevate knowledge of environment
how.impact: Mapping of valuable IP assets sets the stage for extraction and increases the risk of significant intellectual property loss.

how.description: Copied sensitive files and uploaded them to a personal cloud drive or external server repeatedly over time.
how.procedure: The attacker compresses, bundles or packages trade-secret files and sends them via an external connection (e.g., personal cloud, FTP, remote server) over encrypted or non-standard channels to avoid detection.
observable_evidence: Large file transfer events to non-corporate domains after hours
Outbound connections to external cloud storage or unfamiliar servers
Creation of compressed archives of source code/trade secrets on internal hosts
how.impact: Repeated stealing of confidential documents/trade secrets results in cumulative loss of competitive advantage and potential legal/regulatory liability.
